question.title: how to know which constructor was used in creating an object?

node.contents: This sounds like one of those "I don't really know why you're trying to do this, but it's a bad idea" situations. You may want to clarify and add some details if you can.

astNode.text: This sounds like one of those "I don't really know why you're trying to do this, but it's a bad idea" situations. You may want to clarify and add some details if you can.

node.contents: Also, if this is possible at all, we'd need to know what language you're talking about. C#? C++? Javascript? Java?

astNode.text: Also, if this is possible at all, we'd need to know what language you're talking about. C#? C++? Javascript? Java?

node.contents: What is the purpose of this? It seems like this is a "tagged" class, and possibly should be separated into 2 classes. More info would give a better answer.

astNode.text: What is the purpose of this? It seems like this is a "tagged" class, and possibly should be separated into 2 classes. More info would give a better answer.

elements.contents: a1.show(); a2.show(); new A(3).show(); and new A(2,"bar").show();

node.contents: If I wanted to differentiate between these show methods based on the objects (a1 and a2) as well as based on class instance expression (calling show directly on constructors) and did not know which constructor was used (especially for the objects a1 and a2) how do I find that out--say reflectively?

astNode.text: If I wanted to differentiate between these show methods based on the objects (a1 and a2) as well as based on class instance expression (calling show directly on constructors) and did not know which constructor was used (especially for the objects a1 and a2) how do I find that out--say reflectively?

node.contents: It may be important to note that the constructor may not always be called to create the object, so this solution won't work, in general.

astNode.text: It may be important to note that the constructor may not always be called to create the object, so this solution won't work, in general.

node.contents: silky: How, pray-tell, do you create an object in Java without calling its constructor?

astNode.text: silky: How, pray-tell, do you create an object in Java without calling its constructor?

node.contents: R: To be fair, when I commented on that the poster hadn't confirmed the language; I'm not a regular Java user, but I've been hinted to the fact that it is possible via `sun.misc.Unsafe`. Further research required; feel free to carry it out and report back :)

astNode.text: R: To be fair, when I commented on that the poster hadn't confirmed the language; I'm not a regular Java user, but I've been hinted to the fact that it is possible via `sun.misc.Unsafe`. Further research required; feel free to carry it out and report back :)

node.contents: Maybe A should be two different classes (each with a different constructor); or two different subclasses of a common base class: in that way, each class could have it's own distinct implementation of the show method.

astNode.text: Maybe A should be two different classes (each with a different constructor); or two different subclasses of a common base class: in that way, each class could have it's own distinct implementation of the show method.

node.contents: Alternatively, have a data member inside A (perhaps a boolean, or the string) whose value is set differently by each constructor.

astNode.text: Alternatively, have a data member inside A (perhaps a boolean, or the string) whose value is set differently by each constructor.

node.contents: It is not possible to determine by reflection which constructor was used to instantiate an object. Why not simply set an instance variable to a different value in each constructor to track which one was called?

astNode.text: It is not possible to determine by reflection which constructor was used to instantiate an object. Why not simply set an instance variable to a different value in each constructor to track which one was called?

node.contents: So all four ways of calling show should perform a difference action?

astNode.text: So all four ways of calling show should perform a difference action?

node.contents: Why and what is the difference between each of the actions?

astNode.text: Why and what is the difference between each of the actions?

node.contents: Without knowing more we can only make wild guesses. It does sound like a job for two or maybe even four classes (plus an base class/interface) and a factory to create them.

astNode.text: Without knowing more we can only make wild guesses. It does sound like a job for two or maybe even four classes (plus an base class/interface) and a factory to create them.

node.contents: If the question is purely theoretical - No, you can not tell at run time the difference between:

node.contents: The only way to do so would be to exam the source¹, so you would have to include the source and compile with full source numbers included. The parse the source code to work out how it was called.

astNode.text: The only way to do so would be to exam the source¹, so you would have to include the source and compile with full source numbers included. The parse the source code to work out how it was called.

node.contents: If two classes have different sets of behavior then they are two distinct classes. A single class should not behave differently based on how it was constructed.

astNode.text: If two classes have different sets of behavior then they are two distinct classes. A single class should not behave differently based on how it was constructed.

node.contents: Agree that you're better off using two separate classes, in which case you could use polymorphism (example in C#),

astNode.text: Agree that you're better off using two separate classes, in which case you could use polymorphism (example in C#),

elements.contents: public class Base { public BaseClass() public virtual void Show { // show stuff } } public class A : Base { public A(int i) public override void Show() { // show A stuff } } public class B : Base { public B(int i, String s) public override void Show() { // show B stuff } }

declarations.text: public BaseClass() public virtual void Show

comments.text: // show stuff } } public class A : Base { public A(int i) public override void Show() { // show A stuff } } public class B : Base { public B(int i, String s) public override void Show() { // show B stuff } }

node.contents: and it should be easy to differentiate between these show methods based on the a1 and a2 objects.

astNode.text: and it should be easy to differentiate between these show methods based on the a1 and a2 objects.

node.contents: The only way to do this would be to have each constructor set a different variable to indicate that it was used.

astNode.text: The only way to do this would be to have each constructor set a different variable to indicate that it was used.

node.contents: But I agree with Tom; this sounds like a bad idea. It shouldn't matter how you created an object (because a constructor may not even have been used at all, say, in serialisation), it should only matter that all it's properties (public or not) are set appropriately, to reflect the state it needs to be in.

astNode.text: But I agree with Tom; this sounds like a bad idea. It shouldn't matter how you created an object (because a constructor may not even have been used at all, say, in serialisation), it should only matter that all it's properties (public or not) are set appropriately, to reflect the state it needs to be in.
